Additional Information: First attempted launch beyond Earth orbit; failed to orbit due to turbopump gearbox malfunction resulting in first-stage explosion. Reached apogee of 16 kilometres (10 mi). ([3][4])
Failed to orbit; rocket disintegrated due to excessive vibration. ([3][5])
Failed to orbit; premature second-stage cutoff due to accelerometer failure. Later known as Pioneer 1. Reached apogee of 113,800 kilometres (70,700 mi). ([3][6])
Failed to orbit; carrier rocket exploded due to excessive vibration. ([3][5])

Failed to orbit; premature second-stage cutoff due to erroneous command by ground controllers; third stage failed to ignite due to broken electrical connection. Reached apogee of 1,550 kilometres (960 mi). ([3][7])
Failed to orbit; seal failure in hydrogen peroxide pump cooling system resulted in core-stage underperformance. ([3][5])
Failed to orbit; premature first-stage cutoff. Reached apogee of 102,360 kilometres (63,600 mi). ([3][8])

Carrier rocket guidance problem resulted in failure to impact Moon, flew past in a heliocentric orbit. Closest approach 5,995 kilometres (3,725 mi) on 4 January. First spacecraft to fly by the Moon. ([9][10])

Second-stage overperformance resulted in flyby at greater altitude than expected, out of instrument range, with 58,983 kilometres (36,650 mi) of distance. Closest approach at 22:25 UTC on 4 March. First U.S. spacecraft to leave Earth orbit. ([9][11])
Failed to orbit; guidance system malfunction. ([9])
Successful impact at 21:02 on 14 September 1959. First spacecraft to reach lunar surface. The impact made the Soviet Union the 1st country to reach the surface of the Moon. ([12])
Returned first images of the far side of the Moon. ([13])
Failed to orbit; payload fairing disintegrated due to design fault. ([14][9])
Failed to orbit; premature third-stage cutoff. ([15])
Failed to orbit; rocket disintegrated ten seconds after launch. ([15])
Failed to orbit; second-stage oxidizer system malfunction resulting in premature cutoff. ([16][15])
Failed to orbit, exploded 68 seconds after launch, at an altitude of 12.2 kilometres (7.6 mi). Second stage ignited while first stage was still attached and burning. ([17][15])
Partial launch failure due to guidance problem; attempt to correct using spacecraft's engine resulted in it missing the Moon by 36,793 kilometres (22,862 mi). ([18][19])
Failed to deploy solar panels, ran out of power ten hours after launch; incidental impact on the far side of the Moon on 26 April. First spacecraft to impact the far side of the Moon. ([18][20])
Solar panels erroneously disengaged from power system, failed 8+3/4 hours after launch when batteries were depleted. Missed the Moon as course correction was not completed. ([18][21])
Failed to depart Low Earth orbit; guidance system power failure prevented upper-stage ignition. ([22][23])
Failed to orbit; guidance failure. ([23])
Failed to perform mid-course correction, remained in high Earth orbit until given escape velocity by orbital perturbation. ([23][24])
Failed to orbit; third stage underperformed due to oxidiser valve failure. ([25])
Failed to orbit; power failure caused by broken connection resulted in premature third-stage cutoff. ([25])
Impacted on 30 July 1964 at 13:25:48 UTC. ([27])
Impacted on 20 February 1965 at 09:57:37 UTC. ([28][29])
Upper stage failed to restart due to guidance system short circuit, failed to depart low Earth orbit. ([28][30])
Impacted on 24 March 1965 at 14:08:20 UTC. ([28][31])
Third stage failed to ignite due to loss of oxidiser pressure, failed to orbit. ([28])
Loss of control after gyroscope malfunction, failed to decelerate for landing and impacted the Moon at 19:10 UTC on 12 May 1965. ([28][32])
Engine failed to shut down after performing mid-course correction manoeuvre, flew past the Moon in a heliocentric orbit. ([28][33])
Flew past the Moon on 20 July 1965 at a distance of 9,200 kilometres (5,700 mi). Conducted technology demonstration for future planetary missions. ([28][34])
Attitude control failure shortly before landing prevented controlled descent; impacted the lunar surface on 7 October 1965. ([28][35])
Landing airbag punctured, resulting in loss of attitude control shortly before planned touchdown; impacted Moon on 6 December 1965. ([28][36])
First spacecraft to land successfully on the Moon. Touchdown on 3 February 1966. Returned data until 6 February. ([37][38])
Upper stage lost attitude control and failed to ignite; spacecraft never left low Earth orbit. ([38][39])
Entered orbit at 18:44 UTC on 3 April 1966, becoming the first spacecraft to orbit the Moon. Continued data return until 30 May. ([38][40])
Landed in Oceanus Procellarum on 2 June 1966. Returned data until loss of power on 13 July. ([38][41])
Rocket imparted greater velocity than planned, leaving spacecraft unable to enter orbit. ([38][42])
Orbital insertion at around 15:36 UTC on 14 August. Deorbited early due to fuel and communications interference. Impacted Moon on 29 October 1966. ([43])
Entered orbit on 28 August 1966. Failed to return images; other instruments operated correctly. ([38][44])
One thruster failed to ignite during mid-course correction manoeuvre, resulting in loss of control. ([38][45])
Entered orbit on 25 October 1966 and returned data until 19 January 1967. Completed photography mission intended for Luna 11. ([46])
Entered orbit at about 19:51 UTC on 10 November 1966 for photographic mapping mission. Impacted on the far side of the lunar surface on 11 October 1967. ([47])
Successfully landed in Oceanus Procellarum at 18:01 UTC on 24 December 1966. Returned images and studied lunar soil. Operated until power depletion on 28 December. ([38])
Entered orbit at 21:54 UTC on 8 February 1967. Deorbited and impacted the Moon on 9 October 1967. ([49])
Landed at 00:04 UTC on 20 April 1967, operated until 3 May. Visited by Apollo 12 astronauts in 1969. Some parts removed for return to Earth. ([50][52])
Entered orbit at 21:54 UTC on 8 May 1967, operated until 17 July. Lunar impact on 6 October 1967. ([50][53])
Contact lost at 02:03 UTC on 17 July, two and a half minutes before scheduled landing. May have exploded or impacted Moon. ([50][54])
Magnetospheric probe, studied Moon and interplanetary space. Deactivated on 27 June 1973. Presumed impact on Moon during the 1970s. ([55][56])
Entered selenocentric orbit on 5 August and conducted photographic survey until 18 August. Deorbited and impacted the Moon on 31 January 1968. ([57])
Landed in Mare Tranquillitatis at 00:46:44 UTC on 11 September. Last signals received on 17 December 1967. ([58])
Blocked propellant line caused first-stage engine failure, unable to reach orbit. ([50])
Landed in Sinus Medii at 01:01:04 UTC on 10 November. Brief flight from lunar surface and second landing on 17 November. Last contact on 14 December. ([50][59])
Unable to achieve orbit after second-stage engine failed to ignite. ([50])
Final Surveyor mission. Landed near Tycho crater at 01:05:36 UTC on 10 January. Operated until 21 February 1968. ([60])
Failed to orbit after third stage ran out of fuel. ([61])
Tested communications for proposed crewed missions and studied the mass concentration of the Moon. Entered orbit on 10 April. ([62])
Second-stage engine incorrectly commanded to shut down. Recovered using prototype launch escape system. ([61])
Carried life forms, circled the Moon, and returned to Earth. Landed in Indian Ocean on 21 September, first lunar spacecraft to be successfully recovered. ([63])
Closest approach to Moon on 14 November. Reentered Earth's atmosphere on 17 November; unsuccessful recovery after parachutes jettisoned prematurely. ([61])
First crewed mission to the Moon. Entered orbit around the Moon and completed ten orbits before returning to Earth. Landed in the Pacific Ocean. ([65])
Failed to orbit after second-stage engine shutdown and third-stage engine shutdown. Recovered using launch escape system. ([66])
First launch of Lunokhod rover. Launch vehicle disintegrated 51 seconds after launch. ([67])
Intended to land on Moon and return lunar soil sample. Fourth stage failed to ignite, did not reach Earth orbit. ([66])
Reached lunar orbit, lost contact after de-orbit burn, probably crashed on the Moon. ([67])
First crewed landing on the Moon. Lunar Module landed at 20:17 UTC on 20 July 1969.
Carried turtles in lunar flyby, closest approach of 1,200 kilometres. Returned to Earth and landed in Kazakhstan. ([67])
Third attempt at lunar sample return. Fourth-stage engine failed to fire, re-entered Earth's atmosphere. ([67])
Fourth attempt at lunar sample return. Fourth-stage engine failed to fire, re-entered Earth's atmosphere. ([67])
Second crewed lunar landing. Lunar Module landed on the Moon.
Failed to orbit.
Lunar landing aborted due to Service Module explosion. Crew returned safely to Earth.
Robotic lunar sampling mission.
Technology demonstration for planned crewed missions, returned to Earth successfully.
Luna 17 deployed Lunokhod 1 rover.
Third crewed lunar landing. Lunar Module landed on the Moon.
Fourth crewed lunar landing, first to use the Lunar Roving Vehicle.
Deployed from Apollo 15.
Failed during descent to lunar surface.
Entered orbit around the Moon.
Soft landed on the Moon, returned lunar soil sample.
Fifth crewed lunar landing. Lunar Module and Roving Vehicle used.
Deployed from Apollo 16.
Failed to orbit; intended to orbit the Moon and return to Earth.
Sixth and last crewed lunar landing. Lunar Module and Roving Vehicle used.
Deployed Lunokhod 2 rover.
Radio astronomy spacecraft, operated in selenocentric orbit to avoid terrestrial radio interference.
Interplanetary spacecraft, mapped lunar north pole to test cameras.
Entered circular lunar orbit on 2 June 1974.
Tipped over upon landing, no sample return attempt. Functioned for three days on the surface.
Failed to orbit.
Landed in Mare Crisium, returned lunar samples. Final Soviet mission to the Moon.
Flybys in 1982 and 1983 en route to comet 21P/Giacobini–Zinner.
Designed for flyby, placed into selenocentric orbit. Also carried Hagoromo which failed.
Carried by Hiten, intended for flyby, deorbited in 1993 after Hiten failure.
Series of flybys to regulate high Earth orbit.
Made flybys to reach the Earth–Sun L1 Lagrangian point.
Completed lunar objectives, failed after departing selenocentric orbit.
Communications satellite, made flybys en route to geosynchronous orbit.
Ended mission on July 31, 1999.
Made two flybys en route to Mars.
Flyby to reach the Earth–Sun L2 Lagrangian point.
Impacted Moon in 2006, ESA's first lunar impact.
One component of STEREO mission.
Second component of STEREO mission.
Two THEMIS spacecraft moved to selenocentric orbit for extended mission.
Two THEMIS spacecraft moved to selenocentric orbit for extended mission.
Impacted Moon at end of mission. Okina and Ouna also deployed.
Ouna completed operations on 29 June 2009 but remains in selenocentric orbit.
Impacted Moon on 1 March 2009. China became 6th country to reach the surface of the Moon.
Moon Impact Probe deployed, discovered water ice on the Moon. India became 7th country to reach the Moon.
Moon Impact Probe deployed, discovered water ice on the Moon. India became 8th country to reach the Moon.
Entered orbit on June 23, 2009.
Observed impact of Centaur upper stage and impacted itself. Impacts in USGS quadrangle LQ30.
Completed lunar mission, flew by asteroid 4179 Toutatis.
Impacted Moon at end of mission in USGS quadrangle LQ01.
Impacted Moon at end of mission in USGS quadrangle LQ02.
Ended mission on 18 April 2014, intentionally crashed into the far side of the Moon.
Yutu rover was deployed from Chang'e 3.
Yutu rover was deployed from Chang'e 4.
Demonstration of re-entry capsule for Chang'e 5 sample-return mission.
Demonstration of re-entry capsule for Chang'e 6 sample-return mission.
Attached to third stage of CZ-3C used to launch Chang'e 5-T1. Impacted the Moon on 4 March 2022.
Flyby on 17 May 2018 to designated high Earth orbit.
Entered Earth–Moon L2 orbit to support Chang'e 4 mission.
Did not enter Moon orbit.
Operated in lunar orbit until impacting lunar surface on 31 July 2019.
First soft landing on the far side of the Moon. Deployed Yutu-2 rover.
First soft landing on the far side of the Moon. Deployed Yutu-2 rover.
Crashed into lunar surface after main engine failure during descent.
Orbiter operational, but Lander and Rover were lost during landing attempt due to software glitch.
Returned lunar samples on 16 December 2020. Orbiter is in a distant retrograde orbit around the Moon.
Returned lunar samples on 16 December 2020. Orbiter is in a distant retrograde orbit around the Moon.
Returned lunar samples on 16 December 2020. Orbiter is in a distant retrograde orbit around the Moon.
Returned lunar samples on 16 December 2020. Orbiter is in a distant retrograde orbit around the Moon.
Lunar orbiting CubeSat to test orbital stability planned for Gateway space station.
Lunar Orbiter by South Korea's KARI. Will survey lunar resources and produce a topographic map.
Uncrewed test of Orion spacecraft in lunar flyby and Distant retrograde orbit.
Intended to search for lunar water ice. Spacecraft failure.
Intended to detect water and organic compounds. Spacecraft failure.
Designed to image the Interim Cryogenic Propulsion Stage and collect telemetry.
Intended to flyby the Moon and collect surface thermography.
Solar sail for flyby of a near-Earth asteroid. Spacecraft failure.
Intended to image Earth's plasmasphere, impact craters on Moon's far side, and perform maneuvers.
Intended lunar surface probe with solid rocket motors. Missed the Moon due to communication failure.
CubeSat on astrobiology mission to study impact of deep space radiation on DNA repair.
Intended to orbit the Sun to study particles and magnetic fields. Spacecraft failure.
CubeSat to demonstrate navigation in deep space using innovative plasma thrusters.
Lunar lander technology demonstration. Contact lost during landing due to software bug.
Lunar lander technology demonstration. Lost contact during final stage of landing due to software bug.
Lunar rover demonstration launched with Hakuto-R lander. Lost with Hakuto-R.
Moved from Artemis 1 to Falcon 9. Thruster issues prevented planned orbit and flybys.
Will fly by the Moon in August 2024 en route to Ganymede.
Lander and rover operational. Soft-landed near lunar South Pole.
Launched, attempted orbital maneuver failed, crashed on the Moon.
